title: Shades of Black Color: Names, Codes, Meanings and Uses
excerpt: Black appears in countless shades, each carrying mood, meaning, and purpose. From deep charcoals to soft off blacks, names, codes, and real world uses shape visual identity.
content:
From soft charcoal to deep jet, the world of black is far richer than it first appears. Many people see black as a single color, yet designers, artists, and brands know better. Black shifts in tone, depth, and temperature, and each variation carries its own mood.

Black forms when light disappears, yet creatively it opens endless possibilities. That is why choosing the right shade matters. A warm black feels inviting, while a cool black feels sharp and modern. Below, we move through names, color codes, meanings, and real uses that shape how black works in everyday life.

Dark and Pure Shades of Black

At the deepest end sits Jet Black, a true, intense black with no visible undertones. Its hex code defines digital black across screens. Jet black signals authority, formality, and precision, which explains its dominance in luxury branding and typography.

Another powerful tone is Obsidian, a black inspired by volcanic glass. It often carries subtle reflective depth rather than flat darkness. Designers use obsidian blacks in high end interiors and product design where strength and elegance must coexist.

Onyx Black leans slightly cool and polished. Named after the gemstone, it symbolizes protection and inner power. Fashion brands rely on onyx black for evening wear and tailored pieces that need presence without excess shine.

Soft and Muted Black Shades

Not all blacks want attention. Charcoal Black blends black with gray, creating a softer appearance. It works well for backgrounds, long text sections, and minimal layouts. Charcoal feels professional without feeling heavy.

Ash Black pushes further into muted territory. It contains cool gray undertones, which reduce visual tension. Interior designers often choose ash black for walls, furniture, or accents where pure black would feel too bold.

Another subtle option is Smoke Black, a hazy black that feels airy and modern. It pairs well with neutral palettes and soft lighting, making it ideal for wellness brands or editorial design.

Warm Black Shades

Warm blacks include hidden hints of brown, red, or yellow. Coal Black reflects earthy warmth and depth. Its tone feels grounded and natural, making it popular in rustic interiors and organic branding.

Espresso Black carries deep brown undertones. It works beautifully in fashion, leather goods, and packaging where black needs richness rather than stark contrast. Espresso black feels inviting, almost tactile.

Then comes Licorice Black, a warm yet bold shade used often in typography. It balances readability with personality, especially on light backgrounds.

Cool Black Shades

Cool blacks shift toward blue or green undertones. Midnight Black hints at deep navy, evoking night skies and quiet strength. Technology brands favor this shade because it feels intelligent and refined.

Raven Black offers a glossy, blue tinted depth inspired by feathers. It symbolizes mystery and intelligence, which explains its popularity in art, luxury fashion, and high contrast visuals.

Ink Black also falls into this category. It mirrors the color of dense ink on paper and works exceptionally well for print materials and editorial layouts.

Jet Black

Jet Black (#0A0A0A) is an intense, deep black named after the dense, polished gemstone lignite jet. Historically used in Victorian mourning jewelry, it is darker and richer than standard black. This shade conveys sophistication, luxury, and seriousness. Thus, it is frequently chosen for luxury product packaging, high-end electronics, and formal accessories to imply premium quality.

  • HEX #0A0A0A
  • RGB 10, 10, 10
  • CMYK 0, 0, 0, 96

Pitch Black

Pitch Black (#020202) is a near-total black, taking its name from the dark, viscous residue of distilled tar. It is profoundly dark, often used to describe utter darkness. This color embodies obscurity, the unknown, and deep space. As a result, it is effective in astronomy applications, theater backdrops, and designs requiring maximum contrast.

  • HEX #020202
  • RGB 2, 2, 2
  • CMYK 0, 0, 0, 99

Onyx

Onyx (#0F0F0F) is a strong black inspired by the parallel-banded variety of chalcedony. Prized since antiquity for cameos and intaglios, it has a solid, stone-like presence. This shade represents strength, solidity, and smooth elegance. Therefore, it is commonly used in architectural accents, men’s grooming brands, and interior design for a sleek, polished feel.

  • HEX #0F0F0F
  • RGB 15, 15, 15
  • CMYK 0, 0, 0, 94

Charcoal

Charcoal (#1A1A1A) is a dark grayish-black, directly named after the carbon residue from burned wood. It is softer and less absolute than pure black, reminiscent of pencil graphite and ash. This color suggests resilience, neutrality, and subdued sophistication. Accordingly, it is a staple in modern urban apparel, industrial design, and website backgrounds where a softer depth is needed.

  • HEX #1A1A1A
  • RGB 26, 26, 26
  • CMYK 0, 0, 0, 90

Coal

Coal (#141414) is a dense, slightly warm black inspired by the fossil fuel. It evokes the raw, unrefined material mined from the earth, carrying industrial connotations. This color signifies practical strength, enduring energy, and utilitarian grit. Consequently, Coal is effectively used in workwear branding, industrial equipment design, and graphics seeking a rugged, grounded aesthetic.

  • HEX #141414
  • RGB 20, 20, 20
  • CMYK 0, 0, 0, 92

Ink Black

Ink Black (#050505) is a deep, saturated black modeled after traditional writing and printing inks. It specifically references the deep, fluid darkness of India ink or printer toner. This shade embodies permanence, clarity, and communication. Therefore, Ink Black is foundational in publishing, calligraphy, and high-quality printing where a true, dense black is critical.

  • HEX #050505
  • RGB 5, 5, 5
  • CMYK 0, 0, 0, 98

Obsidian

Obsidian (#0B1215) is a cool, blue-leaning black named after the natural volcanic glass. It captures the stoneâ€™s reflective, sharp, and often translucent edges. Obsidian represents protective sharpness, clarity, and cold elegance. Thus, it is favored in tech hardware, mystical or luxury branding, and designs requiring a sleek, cutting-edge feel.

  • HEX #0B1215
  • RGB 11, 18, 21
  • CMYK 48, 14, 0, 92

Raven Black

Raven Black (#0D0D0D) is a glossy, feathered black inspired by the iconic bird’s plumage. It suggests a subtle, natural sheen rather than a flat matte finish. This color connotes intelligence, mystery, and natural omens. As a result, Raven is powerfully used in cosmetics for deep shine, literary themes, and branding that seeks an intelligent, enigmatic quality.

  • HEX #0D0D0D
  • RGB 13, 13, 13
  • CMYK 0, 0, 0, 95

Midnight Black

Midnight Black (#101010) is a dark gray-black that captures the deepest point of night. It is slightly softer than absolute black, suggesting a sky with minimal ambient light. Midnight Black evokes serenity, the profound, and late-night sophistication. Accordingly, it is ideal for luxury automotive interiors, high-end audio equipment, and evening wear design.

  • HEX #101010
  • RGB 16, 16, 16
  • CMYK 0, 0, 0, 94

Smoky Black

Smoky Black (#100C08) is a warm, brown-tinted black reminiscent of dissipating wood smoke. It carries a sense of texture and organic imperfection, unlike solid blacks. This shade suggests warmth, haze, and organic transition. Consequently, Smoky Black is effectively used in rustic interior design, artisanal product packaging, and photographic filters to create a muted, atmospheric depth.

  • HEX #100C08
  • RGB 16, 12, 8
  • CMYK 0, 25, 50, 94

Eerie Black

Eerie Black (#1B1B1B) is a neutral, medium-dark gray-black with a paranormal namesake. It sits in the visual uncanny valley, neither clearly black nor a light gray. This color embodies unease, the supernatural, and ominous neutrality. Therefore, Eerie Black is a staple in horror genre media, haunted attraction design, and graphics meant to unsettle with subtlety.

  • HEX #1B1B1B
  • RGB 27, 27, 27
  • CMYK 0, 0, 0, 89

Licorice

Licorice (#1A1110) is a deep, red-leaning black that mimics the color of the popular confection. It has a distinct warm undertone derived from hints of brown and red. This shade represents bold sweetness, unconventionality, and rich depth. Thus, Licorice is prominently used in confectionery branding, bold fashion statements, and designs seeking a warm, edible darkness.

  • HEX #1A1110
  • RGB 26, 17, 16
  • CMYK 0, 35, 38, 90

Black Olive

Black Olive (#3B3C36) is a dark, muted green-gray that reflects the hue of ripe olives. It is one of the lightest “blacks,” functioning more as a very dark neutral. This color conveys sophisticated earthiness, maturity, and natural harmony. Accordingly, Black Olive is favored in camouflage patterns, military apparel, and earthy, upscale interior design palettes.

  • HEX #3B3C36
  • RGB 59, 60, 54
  • CMYK 2, 0, 10, 76

Outer Space

Outer Space (#2D383A) is a cool, blue-gray black inspired by the void’s color as seen from orbit. It captures the dark, mineral-like tone of space, not pure black. This shade evokes cosmic vastness, scientific exploration, and technological coolness. As a result, Outer Space is ideal for aerospace branding, sci-fi interfaces, and designs aiming for a futuristic, infinite feel.

  • HEX #2D383A
  • RGB 45, 56, 58
  • CMYK 22, 3, 0, 77

Gunmetal Black

Gunmetal Black (#2A3439) is a dark, blue-leaning gray with a metallic namesake, evoking forged steel. It carries a cold, industrial strength, suggesting durability and precision. This color signifies industrial power, reliability, and technical sophistication. Consequently, Gunmetal Black is extensively used in automotive finishes, tool manufacturing, and tech product design to imply robust engineering.

  • HEX #2A3439
  • RGB 42, 52, 57
  • CMYK 26, 9, 0, 78

Oil Black

Oil Black (#0C0C0C) is a deep, glossy black that mirrors the sheen of crude or motor oil. It possesses a reflective, liquid quality distinct from flat matte blacks. This shade embodies slick efficiency, industrial energy, and modern machinery. Therefore, Oil Black is a powerful choice for automotive detailing, industrial branding, and graphics requiring a sleek, lubricated aesthetic.

  • HEX #0C0C0C
  • RGB 12, 12, 12
  • CMYK 0, 0, 0, 95

Void Black

Void Black (#080808) is an intense, nearly absolute black representing complete emptiness. It suggests an abyss or vacuum devoid of light and matter. This color conveys profound emptiness, infinite depth, and abstract nothingness. Thus, Void Black is effectively employed in astronomical visualizations, minimalist art, and designs aiming to create a sense of overwhelming depth or negation.

  • HEX #080808
  • RGB 8, 8, 8
  • CMYK 0, 0, 0, 97

Carbon

Carbon (#1C1C1C) is a neutral, pure gray-black named for the fundamental element. It is the quintessential color of pencil lead and soot, representing essential matter. This shade signifies elemental simplicity, structural foundation, and graphic neutrality. Accordingly, Carbon serves as a fundamental neutral in architectural renders, sketch art tools, and UI design systems for text and borders.

  • HEX #1C1C1C
  • RGB 28, 28, 28
  • CMYK 0, 0, 0, 89

Soot

Soot (#160F0F) is a warm, brown-black that captures the powdery residue of combustion. It is a textured, imperfect color with clear reddish-brown undertones. This color evokes aged residue, industrial decay, and organic transformation. As a result, Soot is often used in steampunk aesthetics, vintage photographic tones, and designs seeking a weathered, historical feel.

  • HEX #160F0F
  • RGB 22, 15, 15
  • CMYK 0, 32, 32, 91

Ash Black

Ash Black (#1F1F1F) is a cool, lightless gray reminiscent of cooled wood ash. It sits between charcoal and a medium gray, lacking warm undertones. This shade suggests desolation, residue, and subdued finality. Consequently, Ash Black is utilized in post-apocalyptic themed design, somber artistic works, and minimalist interfaces where a cold, quiet gray is required.

  • HEX #1F1F1F
  • RGB 31, 31, 31
  • CMYK 0, 0, 0, 88

Dark Slate

Dark Slate (#2F2F2F) is a medium-dark gray with a slight blue cast, inspired by slate roofing tiles. It is a distinctly rocky and textured color, suggesting durability. This color embodies earthy strength, architectural integrity, and rain-washed coolness. Therefore, Dark Slate is effectively used in building material branding, educational institution design, and websites seeking a solid, trustworthy base.

  • HEX #2F2F2F
  • RGB 47, 47, 47
  • CMYK 0, 0, 0, 82

Shadow Black

Shadow Black (#121212) is a soft, neutral black that mimics the color of a deep cast shadow. It is less intense than pure black, suggesting depth created by light obstruction. This shade conveys subtle depth, dimensional mystery, and background presence. Thus, Shadow Black is fundamental in photorealistic rendering, theatrical lighting design, and UI elements like drop shadows for creating realistic depth.

  • HEX #121212
  • RGB 18, 18, 18
  • CMYK 0, 0, 0, 93

Storm Black

Storm Black (#181A1B) is a cool, blue-gray black that captures the sky before a severe thunderstorm. It has a turbulent, atmospheric quality with a distinct chill. This color signifies impending force, atmospheric tension, and natural power. Accordingly, Storm Black is chosen for outdoor adventure gear, weather technology apps, and dramatic cinematic color grading.

  • HEX #181A1B
  • RGB 24, 26, 27
  • CMYK 11, 4, 0, 89

Phantom Black

Phantom Black (#0E0E10) is a very dark blue-black with a hint of purple, suggesting otherworldly presence. It is the color of deep space with a spectral, elusive quality. This color evokes elusiveness, spectral mystery, and nocturnal stealth. As a result, Phantom Black is popular in luxury automotive paints, gaming peripherals, and branding for exclusive, enigmatic products.

  • HEX #0E0E10
  • RGB 14, 14, 16
  • CMYK 12, 12, 0, 94

Matte Black

Matte Black (#1D1D1D) is a flat, non-reflective black that absorbs light evenly. It eliminates all gloss, providing a velvety, tactile visual surface. This shade signifies understated luxury, modern minimalism, and tactile sophistication. Consequently, Matte Black is dominant in high-end electronics, stealth product design, and contemporary art galleries where reflection is undesirable.

  • HEX #1D1D1D
  • RGB 29, 29, 29
  • CMYK 0, 0, 0, 89

Gloss Black

Gloss Black (#030303) is a high-shine, reflective black that mimics polished lacquer. It is often pure black with a specular highlight, suggesting a wet or finished surface. This color embodies high-glamour, sleek modernity, and liquid depth. Therefore, Gloss Black is iconic for grand pianos, luxury vehicles, and consumer packaging where a shiny, premium finish is critical.

  • HEX #030303
  • RGB 3, 3, 3
  • CMYK 0, 0, 0, 99

Soft Black

Soft Black (#1B1C1E) is a gentle, blue-gray black that is easy on the eyes. It is slightly desaturated and often used as a background to reduce stark contrast. This shade conveys accessibility, soothing depth, and modern comfort. Thus, Soft Black is widely adopted in dark mode UI/UX design, e-reader backgrounds, and contemporary office furnishings.

  • HEX #1B1C1E
  • RGB 27, 28, 30
  • CMYK 10, 7, 0, 88

Rich Black

Rich Black (#010203) is a printing formula combining cyan, magenta, yellow, and black (CMYK) for a deeper tone. It is a technical color designed to prevent a washed-out appearance on press. This color represents professional print quality, density, and technical precision. Accordingly, Rich Black is essential in high-fidelity printing, professional graphic design, and brand identity manuals.

  • HEX #010203
  • RGB 1, 2, 3
  • CMYK 67, 33, 0, 99

True Black

True Black (#000001) is a digital near-black, often one value off pure black to avoid crushing in displays. It is a technical solution for maintaining shadow detail on screens. This shade signifies digital optimization, perceived depth, and technical nuance. As a result, True Black is used by digital filmmakers, UI/UX designers, and photographers to preserve detail in dark scenes.

  • HEX #000001
  • RGB 0, 0, 1
  • CMYK 100, 100, 0, 100

Black Pearl

Black Pearl (#1E272C) is a dark, blue-gray black with a subtle iridescent quality, named for the exotic gemstone. It evokes the deep, shifting colors of Tahitian black pearls under light. This color signifies exotic luxury, mysterious elegance, and oceanic depth. Consequently, Black Pearl is prominently used in high-end jewelry branding, luxury yacht interiors, and cosmetics for a sophisticated, unique darkness.

  • HEX #1E272C
  • RGB 30, 39, 44
  • CMYK 32, 11, 0, 83

Black Rock

Black Rock (#0D0332) is an incredibly deep violet-black, leaning heavily into indigo tones. It resembles the color of certain minerals or a night sky with intense atmospheric scattering. This shade embodies mystical depth, midnight royalty, and cosmic mystery. Therefore, Black Rock is effective for astrological themes, music festival visuals, and designs requiring a dark, vibrant base.

  • HEX #0D0332
  • RGB 13, 3, 50
  • CMYK 74, 94, 0, 80

Black Leather

Black Leather (#1A1A18) is a warm, brown-tinged black that mimics dyed leather. It has a subtle, organic texture and a slight sheen, suggesting wear and durability. This color conveys classic ruggedness, refined craftsmanship, and timeless style. Thus, Black Leather is a staple in fashion apparel, automotive interiors, and product design aiming for a premium, tactile feel.

  • HEX #1A1A18
  • RGB 26, 26, 24
  • CMYK 0, 0, 8, 90

Dark Charcoal

Dark Charcoal (#222222) is a neutral, medium-dark gray that is lighter than pure charcoal. It serves as a versatile, foundational dark neutral in design systems. This shade represents urban modernity, balanced neutrality, and structural simplicity. Accordingly, Dark Charcoal is fundamental for modern typography, architectural detailing, and interface design as a primary text or border color.

  • HEX #222222
  • RGB 34, 34, 34
  • CMYK 0, 0, 0, 87

Nightfall

Nightfall (#0B0B0F) is a deep blue-black that captures the moment just after sunset. It holds more color and dimension than a flat black, suggesting a fading sky. This color evokes transition, calm anticipation, and nocturnal beginning. As a result, Nightfall is ideal for navigation app interfaces, evening event branding, and ambient lighting design.

  • HEX #0B0B0F
  • RGB 11, 11, 15
  • CMYK 27, 27, 0, 94

Abyss

Abyss (#0A0F14) is a profound, cool black with strong blue undertones, evoking the lightless depths of the ocean. It suggests immense pressure and unknown vastness, rather than empty space. This color signifies unfathomable depth, cold pressure, and marine mystery. Consequently, Abyss is powerfully used in deep-sea exploration themes, sci-fi environments, and designs meant to convey overwhelming scale.

  • HEX #0A0F14
  • RGB 10, 15, 20
  • CMYK 50, 25, 0, 92

Caviar

Caviar (#0F0F0F) is a deep, neutral black named after the luxurious salted roe. It implies a premium, indulgent, and finely processed quality. This shade embodies opulent simplicity, gourmet luxury, and refined taste. Therefore, Caviar is a classic choice for high-end fashion, luxury cosmetics packaging, and fine dining branding to signal exclusivity.

  • HEX #0F0F0F
  • RGB 15, 15, 15
  • CMYK 0, 0, 0, 94

Black Licorice

Black Licorice (#1A1212) is a warm, red-brown black specifically referencing the candy’s distinct hue. It is richer and more chromatic than neutral black, with a noticeable earthy warmth. This color conveys bold flavor, nostalgic sweetness, and unconventional darkness. Thus, Black Licorice is effectively used in food product marketing, retro design schemes, and branding for distinctive, bold products.

  • HEX #1A1212
  • RGB 26, 18, 18
  • CMYK 0, 31, 31, 90

Black Panther

Black Panther (#121212) is a sleek, powerful black inspired by the iconic big cat’s fur. It suggests a muscular, graceful, and predatory darkness with a hidden potential for movement. This shade represents stealthy power, agile elegance, and protected mystery. Accordingly, Black Panther is frequently chosen for athletic wear, performance automotive design, and media branding for strength and sleekness.

  • HEX #121212
  • RGB 18, 18, 18
  • CMYK 0, 0, 0, 93

Vantablack (Inspired)

Vantablack (Inspired) (#040404) is a digital representation of the world’s darkest artificial substance. It aims to mimic the near-total light absorption that makes 3D objects appear 2D. This color evokes scientific extreme, perceptual illusion, and absolute void. As a result, this inspired shade is used in conceptual art, advanced technology demos, and designs exploring perception and depth.

  • HEX #040404
  • RGB 4, 4, 4
  • CMYK 0, 0, 0, 98

Black Smoke

Black Smoke (#161616) is a medium, neutral gray-black that visualizes thick, dissipating smoke. It is less about soot and more about the opaque, rolling clouds produced by combustion. This color signifies obscuration, transformative energy, and hazy drama. Consequently, Black Smoke is effectively used in concert or event production visuals, motorcycle culture branding, and graphic designs aiming for a gritty, atmospheric effect.

  • HEX #161616
  • RGB 22, 22, 22
  • CMYK 0, 0, 0, 91

Iron Black

Iron Black (#2B2B2B) is a dark, cool gray that mimics the color of cast or wrought iron. It has a metallic, industrial feel, suggesting strength and durability over polish. This shade embodies raw industrial strength, unrefined utility, and historic craftsmanship. Therefore, Iron Black is commonly found in hardware manufacturing, historical site restoration, and designs with an industrial aesthetic.

  • HEX #2B2B2B
  • RGB 43, 43, 43
  • CMYK 0, 0, 0, 83

Graphite

Graphite (#251607) is a very dark, warm brown-black named for the crystalline carbon used in pencils. It is distinctly warmer than charcoal, leaning into earthy brown undertones. This color represents creative potential, earthly substance, and conductive reliability. Thus, Graphite is a key color in art supply branding, engineering diagrams, and product design for tools and writing instruments.

  • HEX #251607
  • RGB 37, 22, 7
  • CMYK 0, 41, 81, 85

Dark Matter

Dark Matter (#101418) is a cool, blue-gray black inspired by the unseen material theorized in cosmology. It suggests invisible mass and cosmic mystery, with a distinct scientific coolness. This shade evokes theoretical science, cosmic unknown, and invisible influence. Accordingly, Dark Matter is ideal for scientific institution branding, astrophysics publications, and tech projects with cutting-edge, conceptual themes.

  • HEX #101418
  • RGB 16, 20, 24
  • CMYK 33, 17, 0, 91

Cosmic Black

Cosmic Black (#0C0E16) is a deep blue-black that suggests the color of deep space as seen through telescopes. It is vibrant and saturated with blue, implying distance and stellar light. This color conveys infinite exploration, stellar wonder, and the vast unknown. As a result, Cosmic Black is used in planetarium displays, science fiction book covers, and designs meant to inspire awe and curiosity.

  • HEX #0C0E16
  • RGB 12, 14, 22
  • CMYK 45, 36, 0, 91

Black Steel

Black Steel (#1F2223) is a cool, grayish black with a slight greenish-blue undertone, mimicking weathered steel. It suggests industrial material that has been treated or oxidized, not freshly polished. This shade signifies industrial resilience, functional coolness, and modern infrastructure. Consequently, Black Steel is frequently used in architectural cladding, heavy machinery, and tech product design for a robust, utilitarian look.

  • HEX #1F2223
  • RGB 31, 34, 35
  • CMYK 11, 3, 0, 86

Shadow Gray

Shadow Gray (#2A2A2A) is a medium-dark, neutral gray that represents the color of a soft, diffused shadow. It is lighter than most blacks, acting as a deep neutral rather than a true dark. This color embodies gentle depth, subtle dimension, and background neutrality. Therefore, Shadow Gray is a versatile choice for replacement of harsh black in design systems, interior wall colors, and product finishes seeking softer contrast.

  • HEX #2A2A2A
  • RGB 42, 42, 42
  • CMYK 0, 0, 0, 84

Black Sand

Black Sand (#1C1B1A) is a warm, granular black inspired by volcanic beach sand. It has a distinct brown-gray tone, suggesting texture and natural mixture. This shade conveys unique natural beauty, geological interest, and earthy warmth. Thus, Black Sand is effectively used in travel branding for exotic destinations, organic cosmetic packaging, and landscaping or architectural themes.

  • HEX #1C1B1A
  • RGB 28, 27, 26
  • CMYK 0, 4, 7, 89

Basalt

Basalt (#242424) is a dark, neutral gray-black named for the fine-grained volcanic rock. It is a solid, stony color with a uniform, cool presence, lacking strong undertones. This color represents volcanic solidity, cool endurance, and mineral simplicity. Accordingly, Basalt is commonly applied in monumental architecture, landscape design elements, and designs requiring a stable, grounded dark neutral.

  • HEX #242424
  • RGB 36, 36, 36
  • CMYK 0, 0, 0, 86

Black Coffee

Black Coffee (#3B2F2F) is a warm, brown-black that mirrors the dark hue of coffee without cream. It is one of the lighter “blacks,” rich with reddish-brown tones. This shade evokes rich stimulation, warm comfort, and everyday sophistication. As a result, Black Coffee is ubiquitous in cafe branding, cozy interior design, and packaging for gourmet food and beverages.

  • HEX #3B2F2F
  • RGB 59, 47, 47
  • CMYK 0, 20, 20, 77

Deep Space

Deep Space (#0B1320) is a very dark navy-black, evoking the endless void between galaxies. It is saturated with blue, suggesting infinite cold and distant starlight. This color signifies profound isolation, scientific wonder, and celestial navigation. Consequently, Deep Space is a powerful choice for aerospace engineering firms, astronomy software interfaces, and designs meant to convey epic scale and mystery.

  • HEX #0B1320
  • RGB 11, 19, 32
  • CMYK 66, 41, 0, 87

Black Marble

Black Marble (#1E1E1E) is a consistent, cool gray-black with subtle veining implied by its name. It suggests polished stone, luxury, and timeless architectural elegance. This shade embodies classical luxury, monumental beauty, and sleek permanence. Therefore, Black Marble is extensively used in high-end hotel lobbies, luxury goods packaging, and digital design to impart a premium, polished feel.

  • HEX #1E1E1E
  • RGB 30, 30, 30
  • CMYK 0, 0, 0, 88

Black Velvet

Black Velvet (#0D0D0D) is a deep, plush black that captures the light-absorbing quality of velvet fabric. It implies a soft, tactile surface that absorbs light rather than reflecting it. This color conveys tactile luxury, intimate elegance, and dramatic softness. Thus, Black Velvet is ideal for luxury fashion and lingerie branding, high-end theater decor, and photography backdrops seeking a rich, texture-implying darkness.

  • HEX #0D0D0D
  • RGB 13, 13, 13
  • CMYK 0, 0, 0, 95

Night Sky

Night Sky (#0A0A12) is a deep indigo-black that represents a clear, moonless night atmosphere. It holds a vibrant blue-purple hue, suggesting the sky’s color before full darkness falls. This shade evokes nocturnal calm, celestial beauty, and peaceful vastness. Accordingly, Night Sky is beautifully used in bedroom decor, spa branding, and astronomy-themed educational materials.

  • HEX #0A0A12
  • RGB 10, 10, 18
  • CMYK 44, 44, 0, 93

Tire Black

Tire Black (#141414) is a pure, solid black specifically associated with new rubber tires. It is a glossy, deep black meant to look clean, new, and functional. Blackened Void

Blackened Void (#060606) is an intensified conceptual black, suggesting a void that has been actively darkened or made more absolute. It is a step beyond mere emptiness into a positively reinforced nothingness. This color signifies reinforced emptiness, absolute negation, and amplified nothing. Consequently, Blackened Void is used in avant-garde artistic statements, high-concept tech product launches (e.g., “the void”), and design exploring the limits of perception and materiality.

  • HEX #060606
  • RGB 6, 6, 6
  • CMYK 0, 0, 0, 98

Black Moonstone

Black Moonstone (#1A1C1E) is a cool, gray-black with a subtle sheen, inspired by the feldspar mineral’s dark variety which exhibits adularescence. It suggests a dark base with a hidden, glowing potential. This shade embodies luminous potential, mineral mystery, and cool, hidden light. Therefore, Black Moonstone is popular in mystical and crystal-healing branding, jewelry design for semi-precious stones, and packaging for products implying hidden benefits or magic.

  • HEX #1A1C1E
  • RGB 26, 28, 30
  • CMYK 13, 7, 0, 88

Black Onyx Stone

Black Onyx Stone (#0E0E0E) is a specific, pure black referencing the banded chalcedony gemstone in its solid black form. It denotes a gemological standard of deep, uniform blackness. This color represents gemological purity, uniform luxury, and solid gem darkness. Thus, Black Onyx Stone is a benchmark in fine jewelry quality descriptors, luxury watch dials, and branding that uses gemstone names to denote quality and uniformity.

  • HEX #0E0E0E
  • RGB 14, 14, 14
  • CMYK 0, 0, 0, 95

Black Darkroom

Black Darkroom (#111111) is a practical black representing the lightless environment of a photographic darkroom. It is a functional darkness essential for the development process, free of any light leaks. This shade conveys functional darkness, creative development, and technical necessity. Accordingly, Black Darkroom is conceptually used in photography studio branding, artisan developer packaging, and design themes centered on analog processes and revelation.

  • HEX #111111
  • RGB 17, 17, 17
  • CMYK 0, 0, 0, 93

Absolute Black

Absolute Black (#000000) is the definitive, pure black defined by the total absence of reflected light. It is the theoretical and digital ideal, serving as the anchor point for all other shades. This color embodies total absorption, theoretical ideal, and definitive darkness. As the final entry, Absolute Black remains the essential reference in color theory, digital design codes, and any application requiring the deepest possible black as a standard or starting point.

  • HEX #000000
  • RGB 0, 0, 0
  • CMYK 0, 0, 0, 100

Symbolic Meaning of Black Shades

Black shades speak different emotional languages. Deep blacks reflect power, boundaries, and sophistication. Softer blacks suggest calm, protection, and restraint. Warm blacks connect with stability and comfort, while cool blacks communicate logic and control.

Spiritually, black represents potential and the unknown. It holds space for transformation and endings that lead to beginnings. That depth explains why black never loses relevance across cultures and eras.

How Black Shades Are Created

Every black starts from absence, yet variations appear through subtle mixing. Adding gray softens black into charcoal or ash tones. Introducing brown warms it into espresso or coal shades. Blue undertones cool black into midnight or ink.

In digital design, hex codes fine tune these shifts. Even a change of a few points can transform mood and readability. That precision separates flat black from expressive black.

Uses of Black Shades in Design and Branding

Black shades anchor visual systems. Logos rely on deep blacks for clarity and authority. Websites use softer blacks for comfort and readability. Fashion leans on warm and cool blacks to shape mood and identity.

Interior spaces benefit from muted blacks that add depth without shrinking a room. Print materials use ink blacks to enhance contrast and professionalism. Across industries, black adapts without losing character.

Black never stays simple. Its shades tell stories of control, mystery, warmth, and refinement. When chosen carefully, black becomes more than a color. It becomes a statement.
